questions.text: A 25-year-old woman collapses suddenly after hearing distressing news. What is this phenomenon called? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cataplexy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cataplexy is characterized by a sudden, temporary loss of muscle tone, often triggered by strong emotions such as laughter, anger, surprise, or distressing news. This condition is typically associated with narcolepsy and does not involve loss of consciousness. The episodes usually last less than 1-2 minutes. During an episode, the person may collapse or fall but remains fully aware of their surroundings. The mechanism behind cataplexy is believed to be related to the inappropriate activation of the pathways responsible for muscle paralysis during REM sleep.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Catalepsy: This condition involves a state of immobility and muscular rigidity, where a person maintains a fixed posture for a prolonged period. It is not triggered by emotions and is commonly associated with catatonia.
  • • Option A. Catalepsy:
  • • Option C. Catatonia: A behavioral syndrome where a person is unresponsive and maintains an immobile posture, often seen in schizophrenia, mood disorders, and other medical conditions. It is not directly triggered by emotions.
  • • Option C. Catatonia:
  • • Option D. Catathrenia : This refers to expiratory groaning during sleep, a condition unrelated to sudden emotional reactions or muscle tone loss.
  • • Option D. Catathrenia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cataplexy is the sudden loss of muscle tone triggered by strong emotions, often associated with narcolepsy.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ganser Syndrome is characterized by approximate answers, clouding of consciousness, somatic conversion symptoms, and pseudo-hallucinations, but not by verbigeration.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. She is relieved of these symptoms by either walking or moving her legs. Which of the following drugs is used in treating the condition?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Gabapentin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS) is a sensorimotor disorder characterized by an unpleasant sensation in the legs and an urge to move them, especially at night. It can disrupt sleep and may have secondary causes like iron deficiency. Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin , are first-line treatments.
  • ➤ Alpha-2-delta calcium channel ligands, such as gabapentin and pregabalin

References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ The Management of Restless Legs Syndrome: An Updated Algorithm Silber, Michael H.Earley, Christopher J. et al. Mayo Clinic Proceedings, Volume 96, Issue 7, 1921 - 1937.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department unconscious. On examination, she has pinpoint pupils, bradycardia, hypotension, and shallow breathing. The mother found empty prescription bottles in her room. What is the likely substance? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Morphine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognition of the opioid toxidrome (miosis, respiratory depression, and unconsciousness) is crucial for emergency physicians as prompt recognition leads to appropriate management with naloxone.

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a patient has the right to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision known as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Advance directive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India, individuals can use an "Advance Directive" to state the way they wish to be treated for a mental illness and the way they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. This provision empowers individuals to have a say in their treatment even if they become incapacitated in the future. This is applicable only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions . Individuals can also appoint “Nominated Representative (NR)”, who will help in taking decisions regarding the treatment if he or she loses the capacity to make decision.
  • ➤ only if a person loses the capacity to make mental healthcare or treatment decisions

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian Laws and Mental Health, Page No 42.

questions.text: A patient was started on haloperidol for the treatment of schizophrenia. He develops torticollis, muscle spasm, and trismus. What is the next best step in the management? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Give benzhexol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute dystonia, an early side effect of antipsychotic treatment, is managed by administering an intramuscular anticholinergic medication such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) or benztropine to quickly relieve muscle spasms.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient was brought unconscious to the emergency department after binge drinking 3 days ago. His blood glucose is 580 mg/dL, serum osmolality is 320 mOsm/kg, and arterial pH is 7.32. Non-contrast CT is normal. What should be the initial treatment? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Normal Saline

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS), initial treatment should focus on fluid resuscitation with normal saline before starting insulin therapy, even in alcoholic patients.

questions.text: A pregnant female with bipolar disorder with previous history of 4 episodes and no episode for the past 1 year, well controlled with 750 mg Lithium, now in the third trimester , comes to the psychiatrist. What is the next step in management ? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)

options.label: D

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Decrease dose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, it's crucial to carefully manage lithium dosage to balance efficacy with safety, avoiding both relapse and toxicity.

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for postpartum blues?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Support and education

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: A patient feels that someone is inserting some thoughts in his mind. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Delusion of influence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A delusion of influence involves the belief that an external force is controlling one's thoughts, feelings, or actions. This phenomenon is also known as thought insertion or passivity phenomenon.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute onset of double vision, difficulty walking, and confusion. Given a history of alcohol abuse, what is the most appropriate initial treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intravenous thiamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion, should be treated immediately with intravenous thiamine to prevent serious neurological damage.

questions.text: What is 'mental retardation' now called according to the American Psychiatric Association in its revision of DSM-5? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intellectual disability

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It's essential to understand that the term "mental retardation" is now outdated and has been replaced with "intellectual disability" in clinical settings, especially according to DSM-5, to ensure respectful and non-stigmatizing communication.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1118-1119.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with complaints of confusion and ataxia. Upon examination, nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy were observed. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke’s encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcohol use due to poor nutritional intake and absorption. Treatment include high dose of parenteral thiamine. Ophthalmoplegia responds first to the treatment, ataxia doesnt improve completely in almost 50% of cases.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Match the following? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) A-2, B-4, C-1, D-3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Twilight (A) refers to a transient, impaired state of consciousness often seen during seizures or certain other medical conditions. Therefore, it matches with Impaired level of consciousness (2).
  • • Twilight (A)
  • • Impaired level of consciousness (2).
  • • Oneroid state (B) is a term used in psychiatry to describe a dream-like state of consciousness, hence matching with Oneirophrenia (4) , which is derived from the words meaning 'dream' and 'mind'.
  • • Oneroid state (B)
  • • Oneirophrenia (4)
  • • Oligophrenia (C) is an outdated medical term used to describe intellectual disability or subnormal intelligence. Thus, it matches with Subnormal intelligence (1) .
  • • Oligophrenia (C)
  • • Subnormal intelligence (1)
  • • Paranoid Ideation (D) involves thoughts dominated by ideas of persecution or conspiracy against the individual. This matches with Persecution (3) .
  • • Paranoid Ideation (D)
  • • Persecution (3)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oneroid state is characterized by a dream-like state resembling Oneirophrenia. Oligophrenia refers to intellectual disability, and Paranoid Ideation is centered on ideas of persecution.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Sim’s symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 39, 40, 132; Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 4599.

questions.text: A pregnant mother was on SSRIs. The risk of which of the following is increased in the newborn? ( INICET Nov 2022) Low APGAR score. ADHD. Persistent pulmonary hypertension. Delayed developmental milestones.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) a, b, c, d

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • a. Low APGAR score : SSRIs in late pregnancy can lead to neonatal adaptation syndrome, impacting the APGAR score.
  • • a. Low APGAR score
  • • b. ADHD: Some research suggests a potential link between prenatal SSRI exposure and ADHD.
  • • b. ADHD:
  • • c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension: Late-pregnancy SSRI exposure is associated with this risk.
  • • c. Persistent pulmonary hypertension:
  • • d. Delayed developmental milestones: There's some evidence linking SSRIs to delayed milestones, though it's less consistent.
  • • d. Delayed developmental milestones:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ SSRIs during pregnancy are linked to multiple neonatal risks. They may increase the risk of cardiac birth defects, decreased gestational age, spontaneous abortion, decreased birth weight, suboptimal fetal growth, low APGAR scores, autism spectrum disorders, ADHD and persistent pulmonary hypertension (SSRIs and SNRIs).

References:

  • ↳ Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 687-688

questions.text: Shelf life of blood in a blood bank in CPDA buffer? (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 35 days

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The FDA-approved shelf life of blood stored in CPDA-1 (Citrate-Phosphate-Dextrose with Adenine) buffer is 35 days. This buffer is one of the standard anticoagulant-preservative solutions used in clinical practice. The shelf life or expiration date is determined by the number of red blood cells (RBCs) that survive in the circulation 24 hours after transfusion. A minimum of 70% of stored RBCs must survive in the first 24 hours for the blood to be considered viable.
  • • Shelf Life of Blood in Different Buffers:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 21 days : This is the shelf life for blood stored in ACD, CPD, or CP2D buffers.
  • • Option A. 21 days
  • • Option B. 30 days: There is no buffer with a standard shelf life of 30 days.
  • • Option B. 30 days:
  • • Option D. 42 days: This is the shelf life for blood stored in certain additive solutions, not CPDA-1.
  • • Option D. 42 days:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The shelf life of blood stored in CPDA-1 buffer is 35 days.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nicotine substitution therapy? ( INICET May 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.correct_answer: C. There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is an effective method to assist in smoking cessation. It is used to relieve craving for tobacco by substituting nicotine in tobacco with nicotine in safer forms. Various preparations include nicotine gums, nicotine lozenges, nicotine patch, nicotine spray and nicotine inhaler. Nicotine gum's absorption can be affected by acidic beverages, so it's advised to avoid them shortly before or while using the gum.

References:
